DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 30, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: ATHENS GAMES WRAP UP WITH TAIWAN COMING AWAY WITH BEST RESULT EVER
DOC.DATELINE: Athens, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By CNA reporters and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The 2004 Athens Olympic Games wrapped up with a closing ceremony at the Olympic Stadium in the Greek capital Sunday evening after 16 days of competitions among athletes from 201 countries around the world.
Taiwan came away with a respectable haul -- winning two golds, two silvers and one bronze medal to take 31st spot in the overall medal standings. The result was Taiwan's best ever at the Olympics.
Taekwondo athlete Huang Chih-hsiung, who garnered a silver medal in the men's 68-kg division, led the Chinese Taipei delegation to the closing ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, International Olympic Committee President Jacques Rogge described the Athens Games as the "unforgettable, dream games." Rogge invited all the world's top athletes to meet again in four years in Beijing for the 29th Olympiad.
A few days earlier, the 2004 Athens Olympic Games organizing committee declared Aug. 26 as "Chinese Taipei Day" after two Taiwan athletes won gold medals in taekwondo events on that date.
Chen Shih-hsin, 26, defeated Cuba's Yanelis Yuliet Labrada Diaz Thursday in the final of the women's under 49-kg Taekwondo division to win Taiwan's first-ever Olympic gold medal.
Shortly afterwards, Chu Mu-yen, a 22-year-old male athlete, grabbed gold in the men's under 58-kg division by defeating Mexican Oscar Francisco Salazar Blanco.
It marked the first time that any country has ever won two gold medals on a single day in taekwondo since it became an Olympic event 12 years ago.
The head coach of Taiwan's four-member taekwondo team said that the team's performance was better than expected and that it has become a source of pride for all the people of Taiwan.
The Chinese Taipei team also took home a silver medal in men's archery and a bronze medal in women's archery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NATIONAL POLICY ADVISER DELIVERS SPEECH IN OSAKA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Hsiao Hsin-huang, a national policy adviser in Taiwan, delivered a speech in Osaka Monday on Taiwan's democratic development over the past two decades and the gist of the Republic of China's policy toward mainland China.
Hsiao told the 300-plus audience members that maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait has consistently been Taiwan's top mainland policy goal.

The lecture meeting was organized by the western Japan chapter of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace. The conference goers included representatives of Taiwanese communities in major western Japanese cities, such as Osaka, Kobe, Kyoto and Nagoya, as well as Japanese officials, scholars and business leaders.
In his view, Hsiao said, democracy is a cornerstone for permanent cross-strait peace.

Noting that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have a common interest in peace, democracy and economic prosperity, Hsiao said Taiwan will do its utmost to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Hsiao said Taiwan also earnestly hopes that mainland China can learn from the ROC's experience in carrying out democratic reform over the past two decades.
Mainland China's democratization will contribute to regional peace, security and prosperity, Hsiao added.

He also called on Taiwan expatriates in Japan and the Japanese government to assist Taiwan in gaining representation in the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: HENRY LEE'S 319 SHOOTING REPORT REACHES TOP PROSECUTOR'S OFFICE

TEXT.P: The much-awaited report on the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu just completed by world-renowned forensic scientist Dr. Henry Lee was sent from New York to the office of Taiwan's top prosecutor Monday.

The report package, bound with an "evidence security seal" upon the conclusion of a news conference at a hotel in Flushing, New York, Saturday presided over by Lee, contains the 130-page report, 150 photographs, an optical disc and a letter from Lee to State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa.
The package was received by Taiwan's chief liaison official in New York, Andrew Hsia, and then delivered via diplomatic post to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Taipei before reaching Lu's office.

While outlining the report at the news conference in New York, Lee, who visited Taiwan April 9-11 to examine the wounds of the president and vice president and to inspect the scene of the March 19 shooting, claimed that the election-eve shooting was not a political assassination attempt because had it been, the shooter would have used a more powerful weapon.

Lee quoted the report as concluding that his Connecticut laboratory team, which traveled to Taiwan with him April 9-11, discovered special "tool marks" on the shell casing retrieved from the scene of the shooting.
This, he said, could be a lead for investigators in Taiwan to follow toward solving who pulled the trigger.
At the press conference, Lee suggested that Taiwan law enforcement officials continue to aggressively search for and seize all illegal firearms in the country and "examine and compare all the guns."
Lee suggested that authorities discover exactly where such a gun that was used in the shooting could have been made.
He also suggested that all the videotapes of the event should be re-examined to positively identify the position of the "hot zone" where the shooter would have been standing.
"Let the evidence talk. What counts is the evidence, and it has nothing to do with politics, motives nor investigations," Lee said.
Lee added that there are still many unanswered questions surrounding the shooting because there are so many "unknown factors."

"Unknown factors," Lee said, include the uncertainty of the exact location of where the shell casing actually came to rest after being removed or ejected from the gun, the location of which is still in question; and the amount and composition of the gunpowder used in the bullet.

Lee added that re-enactments of the shooting carried out when he and his team were in Taiwan were only speculative and are of little value without possession of the actual weapon used and a clear understanding of where the shooter was on the street.
He reiterated, however, that the tool marks on the shell casing did give investigators a place to start.
Lee added that the motive for the shooting could become clear once the actual weapon and shooter are found.
He called for the Taiwan public to remain calm and sensible when considering the incident.

When asked about the recent creation of a special "truth investigation commission" by Taiwan's opposition-controlled legislature, Lee urged Taiwan "to listen to the truth and give law enforcement authorities some leeway and let investigators do their jobs."

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party held a series of rallies, including one on April 10 that ended violently, after the March 20 election to protest what they perceived as an "unfair election" marred by voting irregularities and the "bogus" shooting that gave the incumbent president sympathy votes.
Chen beat his competitor, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, by only 29,518 votes out of the more than 13 million ballots cast.
The weapon used in the shooting has never been recovered, and no suspects have been brought in by police.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN ENDORSES CABINET DECISION TO SEND '319' BILL BACK TO LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday endorsed the Cabinet's decision to send the controversial "March 19 Shooting Truth Investigation Special Committee Statute" back to the Legislative Yuan for reconsideration.

The Cabinet decided Friday to send the statute back to the legislature for reconsideration, in effect vetoing the legislation, on the grounds that the statute violates the principle of division of powers and that the special committee to be established under the statute to investigate the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu would usurp the powers of the Judicial Yuan and the Control Yuan.

According to Article 3 of the Additional Articles of the ROC Constitution, the statute will now be referred to the legislature for reconsideration after the Cabinet's reconsideration request was approved by the president.
If the reconsideration request is rejected by the legislature, the statute will then return to the executive branch where it must be signed into law by the president.

According to the Constitution, the Cabinet, with the approval of the president, can return a bill passed by the legislature within 10 days. The legislature has to handle the reconsideration request within 15 days after it is received. If the Cabient delivers such a request during the legislative recess, the legislature has to convene within seven days and must make a decision within 15 days after convening.

To override the Cabinet's veto and uphold the original statute, at least 109 lawmakers -- a simple majority of the 217 seats in the 225-seat legislature that are presently filled -- have to vote infavor of the statute; otherwise, the statute will be invalidated.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said last week that in light of the fact that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party jointly control a slim majority in the legislature, the alliance might succeed in upholding the statute.

Nevertheless, Yu said, the Cabinet has to show it has done its part by pointing out the unconstitutionality of the statute. He urged the Legislative Yuan to shoulder the historic nature of the statute and rescind it.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT REFORM-MINDED SUBGROUP TO TACKLE PARTY NOMINATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A new subgroup of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) comprised of "young reform-minded lawmakers with high educational backgrounds and crystal integrity" will be inaugurated Sept. 2 to serve as a "clear stream" in Taiwan's politics.

KMT Legislator Apollo Chen, one of the three co-founders of the group, tentatively named the Taiwan New Hope Link, said that the group has set several major objectives as their immediate tasks, including pushing for intra-party reforms within the KMT and keeping a closer eye on the Democratic Progressive Party-ruled administration.
Chen said the group's first goal will be to tackle the KMT's nomination system for legislative elections, the next of which will be held this December.

Chen said that the Taiwan New Hope Link, which is expected to be comprised of 15 KMT legislators representing roughly each of the major constituencies nationwide, will propose to the KMT decision-making body that the nomination of the party's legislators-at-large should be more open to allow more KMT members to voice their opinions on the selections.

He claimed that the existing nomination mechanism -- the KMT decision-making body first draws up a recommended shortlist of candidates which is then passed by a vote of KMT Central Committee members -- is not only partial but also lacks the spirit of democracy.

Chen said the Taiwan New Hope Link will suggest that elected representatives, like all KMT legislators, be allowed to have a say in the nominations to better reflect the wishes of all KMT members and supporters.

Legislator Lee Chia-chin, another co-founder of the KMT subgroup, noted that the potential KMT legislator-at-large nominees should be given a "test run" by speaking in a platform presentation so that all KMT members as well as voters can better understand their stances on a variety of issues.

Legislator Chuo Po-yuan, the third co-founder, said that on the shortlist of KMT legislators-at-large there should be representatives from more groups and from more walks of life to deepen the essence of representation.
Members of the soon-to-be-established Taiwan New Hope Link will have an average age of 42 and will each have more than 10 years' experience in politics, Chen said.
He claimed that the group members all have enviable academic backgrounds and are in good social standing, and will be the "new hope of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA PUBLISHES NEW WORK MANUAL FOR FOREIGN LABORERS IN 5 LANGUAGES

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday it has published five bilingual editions of a new work manual for foreign laborers and caregivers to help them understand regulations relating to them and to adapt to the lifestyle in Taiwan.
Five bilingual editions of the new work manual -- Chinese-Thai, Chinese-English, Chinese-Vietnamese, Chinese-Indonesian and Chinese-Mongolian -- are now available, CLA officials said.

In addition to individual foreign workers, the officials said, the new manual will be also distributed to various relevant authorities and groups, including the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, representative offices of foreign workers' countries of origin, manpower associations, the Economic Processing Zone Administration, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, city and county governments and police bureaus, the Aviation Police Bureau and foreign laborers detention centers.

With a view to helping foreign workers better understand Taiwan's regulations governing foreign laborers, housemaids or caregivers and their rights and benefits during their stay in Taiwan, CLA officials said the council will ask foreign labor-exporting countries to incorporate the CLA-compiled new work manual into their pre-job training courses for their citizens intending to travel to Taiwan for work.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTO/SPACE RATIO IN TAIPEI CITY LOWERED TO 1.04:1, SAYS MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: It may be hard to believe, but the parking situation is Taipei City is improving, according to the mayor, who opened a public parking lot in the Hsinyi district Monday.
Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said the ratio of automobiles to parking spaces in Taipei City has been lowered to 1.04: 1 this year. The ratio in 1998 was 1.24: 1, Ma said.
Parking will be free before Sept. 15 at the Chunguang Car Park, where 213 spaces for automobiles and 71 spaces for motorbikes are available.
Ma said that currently there are about 380,000 parking spaces around Taipei City, including 300,000 private ones in or besides buildings and 80,000 public ones operated by the city government.
Four hundred spaces for cars have been turned into parking for motorbikes since he became mayor, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL SETS RECORD EARNING FOR FIRST HALF

TEXT.P: China Steel Corporation (CSC) posted a record high pre-tax profit of NT$28.295 billion in the first half of this year, a 27.04 percent growth over the previous year's level on a business revenue of NT$76.144 billion (US$2.23 billion) , a CSC spokesman reported Monday.
The first-half profit figure accounted for 47.5 percent of the company's target set for the whole of 2004, with pre-tax earning per share hitting NT$2.99.

As the CSC has raised its product prices for the third and fourth quarters, an average increase of more than NT$1,500 per metric ton, the company is confident of achieving the full-year profit aim of NT$59.5 billion, the spokesman said.

Because of the price hikes, the Taiwan's largest steel maker started to make greater profits in July, with its gross earning ratio last month already reaching 40.7 percent, a noticeable rise from January's 35.16 percent, he noted.

As the effects of mainland China's move to cool off its economy have gradually loosened, demand for steel from home and abroad will rebound, further pushing up CSC's earnings, he said, adding that the company is hopeful of chalking up a whole-year profit of over NT$59.5 billion and obtaining a new high in earnings per share of NT$6.29.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has recently adjusted upward its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2004 to 5.87 percent, the largest increase in nearly seven years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONTAINER SECURITY DELEGATION ARRIVES FOR CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: A delegation of technical consultants from the U.S. Homeland Security Department arrived in Taipei Monday in preparation for implementing container security measures at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.

The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in Taipei in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, said delegation members will meet with Taiwan's customs officials and other law enforcement officers in Taipei and Kaohsiung to discuss details regarding implementation of the U.S.-initiated container security plan.

The U.S. government began to implement the plan after the 911 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, D.C. in 2001, with an aim to preventing large-scale smuggling of weapons of mass destruction via containers, AIT officials said.

Noting that Kaohsiung is the fourth-largest port handling goods shipped to the United States via containers, AIT officials said the U.S. government attaches great importance to the security plan for Kaohsiung Harbor.
The United States has implemented container security measures at more than 20 foreign ports around the world, including nine in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND CLOSELY MONITORING MAINLAND TROOP MOVEMENTS IN WAKE OF PULLOUT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will continue closely monitoring mainland troop movements in the wake of a report about mainland China's troop pullout from an island in the Taiwan Strait prior to a scheduled war game, MND officials said Monday.

According to information reaching the MND, about 3,000 troops that were deployed since the middle of this month on Dongshan Island of Fujian province, which is located opposite Taiwan, have been withdrawn recently, the officials said.

The reasons behind the move remain unknown and it is not clear whether the mainland has effectively canceled its annual sea, land and air joint military exercises planned for September on the island, the officials said, adding that the possibility of an emergency deployment cannot be ruled out for the time being.
They said that the MND is keeping a close watch on the movements of mainland troops and that it will step up information exchanges with other countries.
The People's Liberation Army was to have carried out its eighth annual military drill on Dongshan Island in September, which was to have been a mock attack of Taiwan.
Mainland China and Taiwan split in 1949 at the end of a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY 17 STATEMENT SET M'LAND CHINA'S TONE TOWARD TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: A statement released May 17 by mainland China has set the tone for China's current policy toward Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.
An MAC official made the remarks in a council meeting to analyze mainland China's overall situation during the second quarter of this year.
Liu Teh-shun, MAC vice chairman, noted that Beijing's statement was issued three days before the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian for his second term May 20 this year.

It is generally believed that Beijing was using the carrot-and-stick approach in the statement. It sternly warned Taiwan against moving toward independence and at the same time offered incentives such as the resumption of cross-strait talks to establish a mutually trustworthy military framework as well as substantial trade benefits, such as allowing Taiwan agricultural products to be shipped to mainland China if only it recognizes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as belong to one China.

Liu said that the council believes that the May 17 statement set Beijing's basic tone for Taiwan. On the one hand, it makes the recognition of "one China" the premise of easing cross-strait relations, and on the other hand, it wants to deflate international concerns about Chen's second inaugural address.
Also, mainland China has recently stepped up it efforts to woo away diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, a situation that Liu said is a matter of concern.

On mainland China's economy, Liu noted that its economic growth in the second quarter was 9.7 percent. With imports and exports as well as foreign investments continuing to increase, the State Council has tried to cool down the overheated economy, curb the scale of credit expansion, and use trade and industrial policies in an attempt to give its economy a "soft landing."

On its foreign relations, Liu said that mainland China has continued to step up its diplomatic work after the expansion of the European Union to 25 countries in May. Chinese President Hu Jintao, National People's Congress Chairman Wu Bangguo and Premier Wen Jiabao all visited Europe in recent months.
Mainland Chinese leaders have also stepped up their lobbying of the United States and the EU to grant China full market economy status.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF DENGUE FEVER CASES CLIMBS TO 16 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of dengue fever cases in Taiwan climbed to 16 as a new case was reported to the Center for Disease Control (CDC) on Aug. 13, CDC officials said Monday.
The new patient is a 65-year-old man from Pingtung City, according to the director of the center's epidemic prevention section, Lee Tsui-chiung.

Since dengue fever is transmitted by mosquitoes, CDC officials are calling on residents to frequently empty containers that could hold rainwater because standing water is the breeding ground for mosquitoes. Homeowners can face fines of NT$10,000 to NT$150,000 (US$294 to US$4,410) if they refuse to improve the environment in their areas.
Meanwhile, health workers will go to areas suspected of harboring the kind of mosquito that carries the disease and spray insecticide.
Also, travelers to southeast Asian countries should be on high alert against the disease, CDC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESERVISTS TO HOLD TRAINING DRILL IN SEPTEMBER: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday that the Tung Hsin 16 training drill for reservists is scheduled to be held in September simultaneously with the Wan An 27 civil defense drill.

The annual Tung Hsin training exercise was originally scheduled for July, but was postponed to September due to the extensive devastation to mountainous regions caused by typhoon Mindulle in early July, an MND official said.

In addition to testing the reserve forces' mobilization and tactical combat prowess, the Tung Hsin drill will also include homeland security protection measures together with civil defense forces, who will take part in the Wan An exercise.
The exact date for this year's Tung Hsin and Wan An exercises will be announced at a later date, the official said.
In the past, the Wan An drill usually focused on civil air-defense and natural disaster prevention, as well as post-disaster relief and rehabilitation.

This time around, the official said, the training exercise will include anti-terrorist operations, tackling of nuclear accidents, first-aid treatment, anti-air raid measures and other civil defense tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL POLICE FORCE HOLDS ANTI-KIDNAPPING EXERCISE

TEXT.P: A rapid deployment special police force conducted its first anti-kidnapping exercise Monday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Following a botched attempt to capture a notorious wanted criminal in early August, a fiasco that highlighted the embarrassing fact that gangsters may possess more powerful arms than the police, the military has transferred some heavy equipment to the newly inaugurated special force -- including armored vehicles, the military Hummers, helicopters, as well as submachine guns.

In the exercise held in the marine combat arena at the Tsoying naval base, heavily equipped police first threw stun grenades under the cover of armored vehicles and helicopters, with sharpshooters perched on high ground monitoring the situation. Police then gradually zeroed in on the hideouts of the "criminals, " forcing them to surrender even with their powerful weaponry.

Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, National Police Administrator Hsieh Yin-tang and Criminal Investigation Bureau chief Ho You-yi, as well as local police chiefs from around the island, witnessed the drill.

Su, who presided over the exercise, said the special quick response police force will be stationed in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung and will be tasked with responding to major criminal cases such as kidnappings or firefights in local cities and counties.
He expressed appreciation for the equipment and training provided by the military.
In the future, international anti-terrorist experts will be invited to come to Taiwan to help upgrade the abilities of the police, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: The G.O.P. Arrives, putting Sept. 11 into August.
Republican leaders said Sunday that they would repeatedly remind the nation of the Sept. 11 attacks as their convention is opening in New York City Monday for four days. Party aides said the convention would begin with an elaborate tribute to Sept. 11 victims with speeches by Senator John McCain and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, reminding voters of Mr. Bush's role in leading the nation after the attacks.
Wall Street Journal: Bush's big priority; energize conservative Christian base.
In the tight 2004 race, no group is more important to Mr. Bush than evangelicals and Christian conservatives. As Republicans gather for their national convention in New York starting Monday, these religious conservatives are at the heart of a Bush campaign that is turning traditional general-election strategy on its head. Instead of focusing on undecided swing voters, Bush advisers are putting top priority on maximizing voter turnout among conservative constituencies already disposed to back the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES REPORTS OF INFORMATION LEAK AT SEOUL REP OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that no abnormalities have been found in the communications system at the Republic of China's representative office in South Korea.
MOFA spokesman Michel C.L. Lu was responding to media reports that the Seoul office might have been bugged and that some secret files at the office might have been stolen.

Lu said a delegation of MOFA officials and operatives with the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) traveled to Seoul two weeks ago to conduct a regular check on the office's communications system and espionage prevention measures.

"Initial reports furnished by the delegation to the MOFA show that no abnormalities have been discovered in our Seoul office's communications and information storage systems," Lu said, adding that the delegation will produce a formal report Sept. 3.
Lu said the content of the formal report is not expected to differ from the preliminary one.
As to media reports about alleged embezzlement of the representative office's property by former staff members, Lu dismissed the reports as untrue.
According to Lu, the MOFA arranged for four experts from the National Property Bureau to visit Seoul in April this year to check the representative office's assets and property.
"The four experts didn't discover any irregularities or abnormalities during their investigation," Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RECEIVES NEW MALAWI AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun received new Malawi Ambassador Thengo Maloya at the Executive Yuan Monday and expressed hope that Republic of China-Malawi relations will be further strengthened.
Yu noted that the ROC and Malawi have maintained diplomatic ties for 38 years and said that the friendship between the two countries continues to increase.
He also thanked Malawi for its support for the ROC in the international arena and expressed his confidence in Maloya's ability to promote bilateral ties.
In response, Maloya promised Yu that he will do his best to promote ROC-Malawi relations and he thanked Yu for the assistance the ROC has extended to his country.

Many cooperation programs between the two countries have made great contributions to Malawi's development and its people's wellbeing, Maloya noted, adding that he hopes the cooperation will be further enhanced, particularly in the economic field.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR GIVING NATURE RESPITE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian inspected Monday an operation to build a temporary bridge over a stream in Hsinyi, Nantou County, during which he called on developers to give nature some respite.
The bridge on the new central cross island highway was supposed to be finished later that day. while the whole highway, which closed after July 2 flooding, will reopen for traffic Sept. 4.

Expressing his thanks to workers on the site, the president said experts are still contemplating whether the central cross-island highway, which has been disrupted by mudslides in many places, should be restored, and he added that humans should give time to let nature to recover from the disaster.

He told local officials who pestered him for more financial aid to rebuild infrastructure in their districts to give up the concept that people can conquer nature, claiming that many of the disasters triggered by the flood were part of a backlash by nature to excessive development.
Chen said the Executive Yuan will assess the local officials' requests after taking into account the impact of reconstruction on the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASED CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES PRIORITY FOR 2005: CABINET

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan said Monday that increased cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and cooperation, as well as speedier economic transformation will be among six priorities for next year.
The Executive Yuan made the remarks when it presented its overall budget for 2005 to the Legislative Yuan for review. The legislature will open in mid-September.

The Executive Yuan said that in 2005, it will continue to work toward cross-strait cooperation and exchanges so as to strengthen national security. It will also improve its research and development ability for industrial development and will continue to promote financial reforms.
The other three priorities will be to establish a life-long learning education network, restructure government organizations and upgrade social security so as to safeguard social justice.
In explaining the budget, the Executive Yuan said its work next year will revolve around several major items, including solidifying the national identity and building a "normal" government.

It said that to break out of the diplomatic blockage by mainland China, it will insist on the safeguarding of its sovereign national status, on the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and on the country's participation in international peace efforts to shoulder its responsibility as a member of international society.

The Cabinet also said that government reforms will lay the basis for upgrading national competitiveness, adding that in the future, it will continue to work toward the management of government organizations and staff, so as to cut the personnel burden of the government and upgrade its efficiency.

According to the budget proposal submitted to the legislature, the government will have revenues of NT$1.4027 trillion (US$41.25 billion) in 2005 and expenditure of NT$1.6356 trillion, with a shortfall of NT$232.9 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET'S BUDGET PROGRAM SUBMITTED FOR LEGISLATIVE SCREENING

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's budget program was sent Monday to the Legislative Yuan, which will begin screening the government's 2005 expenditure and revenue once it opens its new session in mid September.

According to the budgets allocated by the Executive Yuan, government revenue and spending is estimated to amount to NT$1.4 trillion (US$41.25 billion) and NT$1.63 trillion for 2005, up by 3.9 percent and 2.4 percent, respectively, over the 2004 levels.

The NT$232.9 billion shortfall and old debts worth NT$60 billion are set to incur a financial gap of NT$292.9 billion for next year, which will be managed by the government through issuing bonds and funds.

Budget appropriated for educational and cultural affairs and science research amounts to NT$317.7 billion, the lion's share of 19.4 percent of the total and representing a growth of 3.7 percent year-on-year.
Expenditure earmarked for social welfare projects reaches NT$289.1 percent, making up 17.7 percent of the total and marking an annual increase of 2.6 percent.

Funds going to economic development plans and national defense needs stand at NT$257.4 billion and NT$251.9 billion, up by 5.1 percent and 0.5 percent, respectively. The 5.1 growth rate is the largest increase among all categories.
The Ministry of National Defense also lists an additional spending worth NT$21.8 billion as part of a major military procurement plan that will span 15 years.

The Executive Yuan estimates that Taiwan's gross national product will yield NT$11.2 trillion next year, equivalent of a per-capita income of US$14,463. It forecasts that the country's economic growth rate for the whole of 2005 will be 4.5 percent, with consumer product prices rising by a mild 1.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ON 3-19 SHOOTING DOES NOT RULE OUT POLITICAL ASSASSINATION

TEXT.P: U.S. forensic expert Henry Lee's report on the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian does not rule out political assassination as a possible cause, State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa said Monday.

At a news conference called hours after he received the report, Lu disputed news reports made the previous day that Lee does not think the shooting was an assassination attempt. He noted that Lee did not suggested any motivation behind the incident, but focused only on the identification and analysis of the evidence collected at the scene of the shooting in Tainan.

Lu said Lee's report confirms that the wound suffered by the president to his abdomen was caused by a bullet, that it ran from right to left across the abdomen and that the bullets recovered are not used by regular handguns.
Judging by the bullets used in the incident, Lu said, Lee agreed with the conclusion of the police that a remodeled replica handgun was used in the incident.

Although many people question whether such weapons can be lethal, police records show they have caused at least four fatalities, Lu said, indirectly denying a claim attributed by newspapers to Lee that a more powerful weapon would have been used in the shooting if the shooter was aiming to kill.
Lu said local investigators assigned to look into the case took heart from Lee's findings, which generally affirm the direction they took in their investigation.

Lu, who will retire Sept. 1, said he was glad to receive the report one day before he left office. The 130-page English-language report was delivered by Lee to Taiwan's representative office in New York Saturday and sent to Taipei via diplomatic pouch.

Lu said he has asked for a translation of the report, which he claimed will be helpful in tracking down the shooter, but he added that the report's contents will not be disclosed before the investigation ends.

Lee, who lives in the United States, was asked by the Taipei authorities to help look into the case. He led four American forensic experts that examined the shooting scene, and pored over the evidence they collected at Lee's Connecticut laboratory.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL TAIWAN CAUCUS WELCOMES PRESIDENT'S U.S. STOPOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Four co-chairmen of a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. Congress have sent a letter to President Chen Shui-bian welcoming his transit stops in the United States en route to and from an upcoming two-nation visit to Central America, a Taiwanese group in the United States said Sunday.

Chen will travel to Panama via Hawaii to attend the Sept. 1 inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Martin Torrijos, and will then visit Belize, another diplomatic ally, to sign a joint communique with Prime Minister Said Musa before returning to Taiwan via Seattle Sept. 5.

The Formosan Association of Public Affairs (FAPA) said in a press release that the four co-chairmen -- Steve Chabot (R-OH), Dana Rohrabacher (R-CA), Robert Wexler (D-FL) and Sherrod Brown (D-OH) -- said in the letter that although Chen will only make brief stops in the United States, they believe it will help promote U.S.-Taiwan relations.
They expressed admiration for Taiwan's political and economic achievements, saying also that Chen's re-election has demonstrated the dynamism and solid basis of Taiwan's democracy.

In the letter, they were also positive about Chen's call for dialogues with Beijing in his May 20 inauguration speech, and expressed hope that Beijing will respond positively to Chen's appeal to establish a cross-Taiwan Strait peace and stability mechanism.
They said that peace in the Taiwan Strait is crucial to maintaining peace and stability in East Asia and that Taiwan and the United States should help and support each other.
They also welcomed David Ta-wei Lee, the new Republic of China representative to the United States.
FAPA officials said that Taiwan-born U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) also issued a statement saying that he hopes to be able to meet Chen during his transit stops.

FAPA President Wu Ming-kee said that Chen's transit stops come at a time when the Republican Party is holding its national convention in New York, so that Chen's transit stop will be limited to the West Coast.

But he pointed out that the U.S. House of Representatives has passed two resolutions to request the lifting of the restrictions on high-ranking Taiwan officials visiting the United States in recent months.
FAPA will continue to lobby Congress to lift the restrictions, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY TO GROW BY 4.5 PERCENT IN 2005: CABINET REPORT

TEXT.P: As the government expects the country's economy to continue growing, the Executive Yuan predicts in a report released Monday that its 2005 economic growth rate will be 4.5 percent, lower than this year's 5.9 percent.

In its 2005 budget proposal submitted to the Legislative Yuan for screening in the middle of September, the Executive Yuan forecasts that Taiwan's gross national product will swell to NT$11.2 trillion (US$329 billion) next year, up by 4.5 percent compared to the 2004 level.
The figure will translate into a per-capita income of US$14,463, reflecting an annual growth of US$538 year-on-year, according to the Executive Yuan.

It forecasts that the domestic economy will expand by 4.5 percent next year, lower than this year's 5.9 percent growth rate, as a result of a relatively slowed world economy that is estimated to increase by 3.6 percent for 2005, a level that still outperforms an 2.8 percent average for the last five years.

Taiwan's economy has been on a rising track since the beginning of this year, with its exports and imports in the first half of the year growing by 25.7 percent and 35.6 percent, respectively, over the previous year's levels, it points out.
Investment from the private sector will increase by 28.7 percent for the same period, laying a sound foundation for an economic growth rate above 5 percent for the whole of 2004, it says.

Although the international economic expansion is expected to slow in 2005, the Executive Yuan remains cautiously optimistic about the economic development at home on the back of Taiwan's competitive and value-added industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRICTER SCREENING TO PREVENT ABSCONDING OF MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: To prevent any future cases of mainland Chinese tourists absconding en masse upon arrival in Taiwan, a verification system will start Wednesday to screen prospective tourists from the mainland, the Travel Agent Association of the Republic of China said Monday.

Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the association, noted that the Executive Yuan has passed a review report on the control and management of mainland tourists and will require travel agencies handling mainland tourist groups to sign a self-disciplinary agreement.
The association will also conduct prior telephone verification according to the information provided by the applicants, and the applications will be rejected if the information does not match.

He said that if travel agencies produce fake certificates for tourists, or if their failure to manage the tourist groups results in tourists absconding, they will be suspended of their rights for a period of between one and 12 months, or will be turned over to related law enforcement agencies.

He said that the association will require application forms to be properly filled out, that the contact telephone numbers must be correct and that the work certificates provided by the tourists' employers should bear official company stamps.
If the applicants say they have no relatives or friends in Taiwan, they will not be able to apply to leave the group while in Taiwan.

He said it is hoped through the initial screening of the travel agencies and the second screening by the association, with final rechecking by the Immigration Office of the National Police Administration, the process will become more effective.
On July 13, 17 mainland tourists ran away en masse upon arriving in Taiwan, while another group of 13 mainlanders escaped shortly after arriving at their hotels Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE APPEAL FOR INFORMATION ON MAN IN FILM OF MARCH 19 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Police appealed to the public Monday for information on a man who appears in television footage taken at the scene seconds before the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian took place.
Coming under new public pressure for a breaking of the case after the release of a report by a Chinese-American forensic expert, the police made public again the image of the man caught on camera.

The man in the film mingled with crowd lining the streets to welcome Chen during a campaign parade in Tainan. He was dressed in a white shirt and dark pants, waving a flag of Chen's Democratic Progressive Party in his right hand and putting his left hand in his pocket and looking back repeatedly.
The police said the man appeared in the area where two bullets were supposed to have been fired that wounded the president and Vice President Annette Lu, who was by his side in an open-topped jeep.

Of the 434 persons appearing in the TV footage, 46 are listed by police as possible shooters. Forty of them have already come forward to clear their names, with six remaining unaccounted for. Four of the six can be clearly seen, while the images of the two others are blurred.
Police released a photo of the man captured from the television footage.

In another development Monday, prosecutors assigned to probe the case made public a list of the tasks they have completed in probing the case. The list shows they visited and questioned Scretary General of the National Security Council Chiou I-jen July 7. Chiou was serving as the secretary-general to the president when the shooting took place.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian headed for the Central American states of Panama and Belize for a visit Monday night.

In a brief speech before he boarded his plane at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, the president said he delayed and cut short his trip because of the disaster caused by Typhoon Aere on Aug. 24, saying that although the disaster is of great concern, diplomacy is also vital for the country and is his task.
Chen urged his administration to keep working hard to reconstruct the diaster-affected areas during his overseas trip.
The president will attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Martin Torrijos Sept. 1, traveling via Hawaii, and will continue to Belize Sept. 2.
He will arrive in Seattle Sept. 3 for an eight-hour stopover on his way back to Taiwan and will arrive home Sept. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CANCELS LIVE AMMO FIRE DRILL TO SHOW ITS SINCERITY: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said early Tuesday morning that the government has decided to cancel the live ammunition fire drill of the "Hankuang No. 20" military exercises set for Sept. 9. to show Taiwan's sincerity in pursuing development of cross-strait cooperation based on the principle of peace.

The president made the comments aboard his plane heading for an official visit to two ROC diplomatic allies in Central America following media reports that mainland China had canceled its annual military exercise on Dongshan Island.
Chen will attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Martin Torrijos Sept. 1 and then visit Belize Sept. 2.

Taiwan planned to hold an overall combat training drill of ground and air forces Aug. 25 to cap off the months long "Hankuang No. 20" military exercises, but the Ministry of National Defense was forced to postpone the drill due to Typhoon Aere which slammed the island Aug. 24-25.
Chen also said he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can march toward better cooperation and create a win-win situation.

Although the president did not confirm whether mainland China had canceled its military exercise on Dongshan Island while announcing the government's decision to cancel the live fire drill, he said that regardless of Beijing's intentions, he has decided to cancel the drill following consultations Monday evening with Defense Minister Lee Chieh, who is in favor of the decision.

Defense Ministry officials confirmed Monday that mainland Chinese military authorities have recently recalled about 3,000 troops from Dongshan Island where annual military exercises were originally set to be held. The officials added that the ministry will continue to closely monitor the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REPUBLICAN PARTY VOWS TO HELP DEFEND TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Republicans adopted a party platform Monday supporting President George W. Bush's war on global terrorism and denying mainland China's claimed right to impose its rule on Taiwan.

The 93-page platform, approved on the opening day of the Republican Party's national convention being held at Madison Square Garden in New York City, made clear that the centerpiece of Bush's campaign is his war on terror launched after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks that killed nearly 3,000 people.
"Terrorists long ago declared war on America, and now America has declared war against terrorists, " the platform said. "We are defending the peace by taking the fight to the enemy."

The platform criticized mainland China for seeking military capabilities that could threaten its neighbors, for failing to uphold its commitments to nuclear non-proliferation, and for violating human rights.

Vowing to help defend Taiwan from any move by Beijing to forcibly unify it with the mainland, the platform indicated that "we deny the right of Beijing to impose its rule on the free Taiwanese people."
"All issues regarding Taiwan's future must be resolved peacefully and must be agreeable to the people of Taiwan," it stressed.
The platform also vowed to oppose any unilateral change to the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and other global organizations.
Meanwhile, a Taiwan delegation of legislators and politicians from across the political spectrum is attending the Republicans' national convention as observers.

Three members of the Taiwan group, namely Liu Shi-fang, a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Central Executive Committee; Legislator Sun Kuo-hua from the opposition Kuomintang; and Wang Kao-cheng, an academic and stalwart of the opposition People First Party, were invited to take part in a discussion workshop sponsored by the International Republican Institute, an important politics think-tank that is loosely affiliated with the Republican Party, Monday afternoon.

Members of the Taiwan delegation are expected to meet important Republican politicians, members of several key think-tanks and media leaders in New York in the following days to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, providing a golden opportunity for Taiwan to express its opinions and have its voice heard.

Taiwan's top representative in the United States, David Lee, is expected to travel from Washington, D.C., to New York Sept. 1 to meet the Taiwan delegation as well as Taiwan journalists and camera crews who are in New York to cover the convention.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 MAINLAND FISHERMEN NABBED FOR SMUGGLING TAIWAN BETEL NUT

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese fishermen were arrested for smuggling Taiwan betel nut to mainland China, coast guard officials on the outlying island of Kinmen reported Tuesday.
Tipped off recently that underground transactions across the Taiwan Strait are rampant, the coast guard sent a cutter to step up patrols over the past days.
Coast guard officials spotted the mainland Chinese fishing vessel headed toward mainland China Sunday night after it had received "the cargo" from a Kinmen fishing vessel.

The officials intercepted the mainland vessel and found on board 780 kg of betel nut, 80 kg of unripe piper linn fruit and 15 kg of betel nut leaves of piper linn with a total market value of more than NT$500,000 (US$14,705).

The vessel's captain, identified as Wang Jianhua, and fisherman Wang Jiatai, who both come from Xiamen, Fujian Province, were sent to the Kinmen Prosecutor's Office for violation of anti-smuggling regulations and the statute governing the relations between the people across the Taiwan Strait.
Wang Jiatai said that he was paid 100 renminbi (about NT$4,110) for shipping the goods, claiming he risked being arrested because his family needs the money.
The Kinmen coast guard intercepted 12,000 kg of betel nut being smuggled to Kinmen from mainland China in mid-June. But this time, they seized Taiwan betel nuts.
Though Taiwan betel nuts are more expensive, they are considered to be of higher quality and are therefore favored by Taiwan businesspeople operating on the mainland, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN QUESTIONS CANCELLATION OF LIVE-FIRE DRILL

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on Tuesday questioned Taiwan's decision to cancel a major live-fire drill in response to mainland China's reported cancellation of its scheduled military exercise on Dongshan Island.

Noting that Beijing has not formally announced a cancellation of the military exercise, Soong said Taiwan cannot afford to miscalculate nor misjudge the military situation based on incomplete intelligence.

President Chen Shui-bian said early Tuesday morning that the government has decided to cancel the live ammunition war drill of the "Hankuang 20" military exercises set for Sept. 9. to show Taiwan's sincerity in pursuing development of cross-strait cooperation based on the principle of peace.

Taiwan had planned to hold an overall combat training drill of ground and air forces Aug. 25 to cap off the months long "Hankuang No. 20" military exercises, but the Ministry of National Defense was forced to postpone the drill due to Typhoon Aere which slammed the island Aug. 24-25.

Although the president did not confirm whether mainland China had canceled its military exercise on Dongshan Island while announcing the government's decision to cancel the live fire drill, he said that regardless of Beijing's intentions, he has decided to cancel the drill following consultations Monday evening with Defense Minister Lee Chieh, who is in favor of the decision.

Defense Ministry officials confirmed Monday that mainland Chinese military authorities have recently recalled about 3,000 troops from Dongshan Island where annual military exercises were originally set to be held. The officials added that the ministry will continue to closely monitor the situation.

Meanwhile, a Beijing official with the State Council's Office of Taiwan Affairs in charge of public relations declined to confirm Tuesday whether the combined-services PLA military drills scheduled to begin around the end of August have been canceled or not.

Yang Yi, deputy director of the information bureau under the State Council's Office of Taiwan Affairs, also kept mum when asked by Taiwan reporters about President Chen Shui-bian's gesture of goodwill in calling a halt to the final stage of the "Hankuang 20" exercises.
Yang only said that "you have to look at the situation from a wider perspective" on the development of cross Taiwan Strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPTIMISM SURROUNDS TALKS ON REOPENING TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: Talks between Taipei and Seoul on resuming long-severed air links between Taiwan and South Korea are progressing and the public should be cautiously optimistic about the outcome, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman said Tuesday.

Spokesman Lu Ching-lung made the comments while responding to media questions following reports that negotiations related to the reestablishment of Taiwan-South Korea air links have entered the final stage.

Differences between the two sides have narrowed and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen has agreed to several points in principle and the ministry is optimistic that an announcement could be forthcoming soon.
Regular air links between the two countries were stopped 12 years ago.
Lu also said that the foreign ministry is cooperating with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in the negotiations.

A new aviation agreement would not only be important for the economic interests of the two countries, but would positively affect the relationship between Taiwan and South Korea, Lu maintained. He declined to elaborate on details of the agreement before a document is signed.

Asked whether the ROC government's insistence on sending ministerial level officials to represent Taiwan to sign an agreement has been the main factor preventing the two countries from making a breakthrough on the issue, Lu said that the conclusion of the negotiations is the most important thing, and who signs an accord is immaterial as long as both parties agree on the terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN THANKS KMT HEAD FOR REFORM PROPOSALS

TEXT.P: A former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Lin Yi-hsiung, paid a courtesy call on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Tuesday to congratulate him on the recent passage in the legislature of several constitutional revisions.

Lin, who founded a group to campaign for the abolishment of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and for the downsizing of the Legislative Yuan, said he is glad that by the concerted efforts of the opposition KMT and the ruling DPP, the legislature passed constitutional revisions that include reducing the number of seats in the legislature by about half and changing the legislative electoral system.
For his part, Lien said it was the KMT's responsibility as a major opposition party to see to it that bills on legislative reforms be passed and promulgated.
As a matter of fact, Lien said, he began some 20 years ago to push for a "single seat, two votes" legislative election system and stressed that the idea is by no means a new one.
Reducing the number of legislative seats was also agreed upon by almost all major parties in the country, Lien added.
Lien also said that all politicians should do a great deal of soul-searching to examine whether democratization in Taiwan is being carried out under the principles of fairness and justice.
Lien said he admired Lin, who has been known in Taiwan as a "democracy fighter, " and asked Lin to join him someday to work as a team for the cause of Taiwan's democratization.

Lin, who has participated in a number of hunger strikes and sit-ins over the years to champion his ideals, gave Lien a book written by his daughter, Lin Huan-chun, the only survivor of an unsolved multiple murder in Lin's residence decades ago. She is now a mother of three and a musician living in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HEADS FOR PANAMA AFTER HECTIC TRANSIT STOP IN HAWAII
DOC.DATELINE: Hawaii, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian headed for Panama late Monday after a seven-hour transit stop in Hawaii during which he met with U.S. politicians, visited Pearl Harbor and attended a dinner hosted by major Taiwanese associations.

When the China Airlines plane carrying Chen and his entourage arrived at Hawaii International Airport at 3: 00 p.m., acting Hawaii Governor Mark Benneet, acting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman William Brown and ROC Representative to the United States David Lee boarded the plane to greet Chen.

Hundreds of Taiwan expatriates turned out to greet Chen when he and his entourage arrived at the hotel where he was staying. They waved the U.S. and ROC flags and chanted "A-bian [Chen's nickname]! Aloha" to welcome the president.
Senator Daniel K. Inouye paid a courtesy call on Chen at his hotel. The president also spoke with Brown and Benneet.
Later on, Chen visited the USS Arizona Memorial Museum at Pearl Harbor, which is dedicated to commemorating all military personnel killed in the Pearl Harbor attack in 1941.
In the evening, Chen attended a dinner hosted by Taiwanese associations in Hawaii.
After the dinner, Chen and his entourage left for Panama to attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Martin Torrijos Sept. 1.
Chen is scheduled to travel to Belize Sept. 2 for an official visit. He will make an eight-hour stopover in Seattle on his way back to Taiwan on Sept. 5.
