DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS GETS REPATRIATIONS BACK ON TRACK

TEXT.P: Taiwan repatriated 178 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants Tuesday with the help of the Red Cross after a hiatus of more than five months.
The illegals, 95 women (including one baby girl) and 83 men, had been staying in a detention center on the outlying island of Matsu.

Hau Lung-bin, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, who was in Matsu to witness the operations along with his counterpart from the mainland, said he was happy that cross-strait cooperation helped to bring about the operation.

Hau noted that mainland China sent its last repatriation ship on March 12, and that no others were sent because of inclement weather and the fact that the ship used for the purpose was undergoing annual maintenance.
As a result, detention centers in Matsu as well as in Taiwan proper have become overwhelmed with around 2,800 Chinese illegals, far surpassed the capacity of the facilities.
Hau said Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan had asked the Red Cross Society for help.

Based on humanitarian concerns, he said the Red Cross Society contacted its mainland counterpart two months ago to request assistance in helping resume repatriations and was happy to learn last week that Beijing has agreed.

He expressed the hope that both sides can resume three repatriation trips every two months, and that the trips could take place more frequent before the Mid-Autumn Festival, a traditional family reunion day for Chinese that falls on Sept. 28 this year.
"This will allow the illegals to reunite with their families, and also ease the burden on the detention centers, " Hau said.
Fifty-two people are still being held in Matsu after Tuesday's repatriation, but there are more than 2,000 still detained in Taiwan as a whole.

Meanwhile, mainland China also sent back to Taiwan five wanted Taiwan criminals -- drug convicts Ke Chin-kun and Chen Hsi-Chung; blackmail convict Hsu Tze-hsin; and gangsters Hsieh Kuo-tung and Han Chi-kai -- and Lu Yu-chuang who entered mainland China illegally.
The six were brought back to Taipei after initial questioning by police in Matsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCELLATION OF LIVE-FIRE DRILL HELPFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MND

TEXT.P: The government's decision to cancel the "Hankuang No. 20" live-fire military exercises will help reduce cross-Taiwan Strait tensions, Ministry of National Defense officials said Tuesday.
President Chen Shui-bian confirmed earlier that the drill originally set for Sept. 9 would be canceled to show Taiwan's sincerity in pursuing cross-strait peace and cooperation.
The decision came after mainland China recalled about 3,000 troops from Dongshan Island where annual military exercises were originally set to be held.
ROC Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Taiwan's decision is reciprocal because Beijing's move may have been a goodwill gesture.
Lee, meanwhile, said the "Tung Hsin 16" training drill for reservists and the "Wan An 27" civil defense drill will be held as planned in September.

The annual "Tung Hsin" training exercise was originally scheduled for July, but was postponed to September due to the extensive devastation to central mountainous regions caused by Typhoon Mindulle in early July.
In addition to testing the reserve forces' mobilization and tactical combat prowess, the joint exercises will also include homeland security protection measures such as anti-terrorist operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION FAVORS FORMER JUDICIAL YUAN HEAD AS COMMISSION CHAIR

TEXT.P: The opposition is planning to designate former Judicial Yuan president Shih Chi-yang to chair their "truth investigation commission" for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, reliable sources said Tuesday.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) , which holds a small majority in the Legislative Yuan, pushed through a special statute last week to make possible the commission's formation.
According to the law, the commission will be made up of 17 professionals recommended by various political parties, including five by the KMT and four by the PFP.
A chairman will be elected from among the commission members.

The sources said the KMT has already decided on its choices, including Shih, former State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Han, lawyer Wang Ching-feng, coroner Yang Jih-sung and the another identified only by his surname, Huang.
The KMT believes Shih's credentials and professional background will make him the best candidate for the chairmanship and is confident he will win the PFP's endorsement, the sources said.

The Executive Yuan is expected to request the legislature to reconsider the bill, calling the commission unconstitutional. But it is uncertain as to whether the bill will be overruled in view of the dominance enjoyed by the opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MISSION TO VISIT RUSSIA TO BOLSTER TRADE

TEXT.P: A Taiwan mission is scheduled to depart for Russia Sept. 5 to bolster Taiwan-Russia ties in business, trade, the sciences and humanitarian aid, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported Tuesday.

The 42-member Taiwan mission, to be headed by Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and vice chairman of the Taiwan-Russia Association, is scheduled to visit Russia Sept. 5-13, said Tseng Ching-yuan, director-general of the MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs.

Topping the mission's itinerary is attending the second Taiwan-Russia Cooperation Forum for discussions on loans for small- and medium-sized enterprises as well as development of science-based industrial parks, according to Tseng.
During their eight-day stay, the Taiwan group will meet representatives from Russia's business and trade sectors for a series of talks.
Tseng said that there will be a contract signing ceremony, featuring contracts for orders worth over US$100 million to be placed by Taiwan businesses for Russian goods.

In addition, he said, Wu and his group members will sign an agreement with the Russian Ministry of Health and Social Development on Taiwan's donation of US$200,000 for the purchase of convertible X-ray inspection equipment to be used in the Altai Krai territory located in the remote area bordering Russia, Mongolia, China and Kazakhstan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE COUNCIL TO LAUNCH DRIVE AGAINST SMUGGLED MAINLAND GOODS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture is planning a drive to build public awareness against illegal agricultural products smuggled in from mainland China, a council spokesman said Tuesday.

The council will launch the intensive campaign through a variety of mass media outlets, including TV, newspapers, radio, magazines, web sites and bus ads. They will focus on promoting Taiwan consumers' awareness against illegal agricultural products from the mainland, the spokesman said.

The council will introduce effective methods to help the public distinguish differences between domestic and mainland farm produce as part of its efforts to secure food safety for local consumers in view of rampant smuggled mainland agricultural goods in the home market, he said.
In addition to the publicity campaign, he said that government authorities have also stepped up efforts to block contraband goods coming from the mainland.

During the first seven months of this year, the government destroyed as much as 972 metric tons of smuggled agricultural and poultry products, such as peanuts, rice, small red beans, dry mushrooms, garlic, betel nuts, tea and fruits.

In a bid to wipe out false product origin certificates issued by other countries, the council has also asked relevant government agencies to strengthen their scrutiny of such documents and import contracts, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES TAIWAN CANCELLATION OF LIVE-FIRE MILITARY DRILL: AIT
DOC.DATELINE: Hawaii, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has welcomed and recognizes Taiwan's decision to cancel its planned "Hankuang No. 20" live-fire military drill to signify its resolve to promote peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the acting chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Monday.

William Brown made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian announced aboard a flight from Taipei to Hawaii earlier in the day that Taiwan's armed forces have decided to cancel the live-fire military exercise scheduled for Sept. 9 -- the finale of the months-long "Hankuang" series of combined-services training drills.
Brown traveled to Hawaii from the U.S. mainland to greet Chen who made a seven-hour transit stop en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Martin Torrijos Sept. 1.

The acting top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries said the U.S. government welcomes Taiwan's decision to cancel its planned military exercise as a goodwill gesture to mainland China.

Prior to Chen's departure for Hawaii for a hectic transit stop en route to Panama, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed that mainland China has withdrawn about 3,000 ground troops from Dongshan Island, prompting speculation that Beijing may have canceled plans for further war games there.
Dongshan Island, which lies opposite Taiwan, was the scene of a major mainland military drill in May, when 18,000 troops from the People's Liberation Army simulated an invasion of Taiwan.
MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said more than 3,000 ground troops moved to Dongshan in mid-August had since been gradually pulled out.
"Given the development, the likelihood of a drill is quite low but we will continue to watch the situation," Huang said.

Chen told reporters during the flight from Taiwan to Hawaii that no matter whether Beijing has really canceled its military maneuvering plan, he is determined to cancel the "Hankuang" live-fire drill after consultations with Minister of National Defense Li Jye, who Chen said was in favor of the cancellation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRACKDOWN ON GRAFT AND TEXTBOOK PIRACY TOP PRIORITY: JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Tuesday that his ministry will dedicate itself to ending graft and protecting intellectual property rights for textbooks in the next two years.
Chen made the promise when he was invited to address a luncheon sponsored by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and the European Council of Commerce and Trade.
Over the past four years, Chen said, the ministry's task of cracking down on organized crime and bribery has been successful and the next step will focus on graft and piracy.
"This is because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has promised those in Taiwan, especially foreigners, that it will create an environment suitable for investment," he said.
He also said his ministry aims to "lower Taiwan's piracy rate to the level of advanced nations, about 30 percent."
He said colleges and universities will start their new school year soon and the top law enforcer said that the ministry wants to achieve good results in its crackdown on textbook piracy.

Chen noted that the ministry conducts raids on copying shops near school campus every September when a new school year begins, and these have been successful, although the ministry has also noticed that pirating has moved on-campus.
"The ministry will work with the Ministry of Education on how to enter school campuses to effectively enforce the law," Chen said.

Although the law does not stipulate which places are off-limits for law enforcers to search, authorities will handle the situation with tact when entering such places as school campuses, the Legislative Yuan or military barracks to avoid controversy, Chen said.

Chen said that the protection of intellectual property rights (IPR) has been one of his top priorities since he assumed his post four years ago. With the world becoming centered on a knowledge-based economy, if a government cannot effectively protect IPR, then enterprises and individuals will have no interest in investing in research and development, a situation he said will seriously affect a nation's development and creativity.
As to whether local students can afford the steep prices of foreign textbooks, Chen said that bookshops should be able to cut their prices.

He said that all intellectual property has its own particular knock-off market. In addition to textbook piracy, the marketing of fake medicines is very serious; still worse, most fake medicines are sold through professional pharmacies, doing much harm to the public. For this reason, the ministry organized a concerted crackdown on pharmacies across the island in July 2004 and called on pharmacists to refuse to sell medicines with unidentified origins.

He also talked about the most formidable challenge that comes from Internet piracy, but he said that the new revised copyright law has been approved by a provisional session of the Legislative Yuan, addressing concerns about criminal penalties and protection of high technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES RICE TO MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate 120 tons of rice to Mongolia, which is facing a food shortage, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Tseng Ching-yuan, director of the MOFA's West Asian Affairs Department, said the first shipment of 100 tons will be shipped Sept. 10 and is scheduled to arrive in Mongolia in early October.
The World Vision charity's Mongolia chapter will be responsible for distributing the rice, Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 63 PERCENT OF CHILDREN HAVE BEEN BULLIED AT SCHOOL: POLL

TEXT.P: Sixty-three percent of elementary school students have been bullied at schools while 66 percent are aware of school bullies, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) among 460 elementary school children.
CWLF officials said they have received nearly 100 complaints about children being bullied at school since the recent launch of a children's hotline.
A number of parents and teachers have also complained that their children have refused to go to school over fear of being bullied.
The survey found that more than 50 percent of the respondents have occasionally been bullied, while nearly 10 percent said they are bullied constantly.
Only 36 percent of the respondents said they have never been bullied.
In more than 50 percent of bullying cases, the children were bullied verbally, the survey shows, while 36 percent suffered physical bullying and 27 percent were bullied by being ostracized.

When bullied, 41 percent of the respondents said they simply endured it, 33 percent said they tell their parents, 28 percent said they tell their teachers and 10 percent said they take retaliatory action.
Less than 10 percent of those surveyed said they would take the initiative to help a bullied schoolmate, according to the poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXAS REPUBLICANS CALL FOR RECOGNITION OF TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Texas Republican Party has called for the recognition of Taiwan as a sovereign and independent country in its party platform and has urged the U.S. Congress to pass a Taiwan Security Enhancement Act to help defend Taiwan.
The Republican Party passed its platform Aug. 30 during a national convention held in New York, in which it stressed that Beijing has no rights to coercively impose its reign on Taiwan.

The platform, which was approved, also states that problems related to Taiwan's future should be resolved peacefully by measures agreed by the Taiwan people, and that if the mainland violates these principles, the United States will react accordingly, including helping Taiwan defend itself.

The platform of the Texas Republican Party has more say on cross-Taiwan Strait ties and strongly recommends the removal of Permanent Normal Trade Relations (formerly Most Favored Nation status) with the mainland unless five conditions are met: A formal peace treaty between North and South Korea; a significant improvement in mainland government policies on human rights; religious freedom on the mainland; a halt to Beijing's aggressive behavior toward its neighbors, particularly Taiwan; and a halt to transfers of nuclear, biological and chemical technology to Iran, Pakistan and North Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPETITIVE IN PUBLIC WLAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to play a leading role in the global public wireless local area networking (WLAN) market thanks to its strong manufacturing clout and full government support, an industry expert said Tuesday.

Wu Chen-sheng, general manager of the Nortel Network in Taiwan, made the analysis while giving a keynote speech at an international seminar on the prospects for the wireless telecommunications industry.

Citing research statistics, Wu reported that the country's telecommunications industry ranks as the world's 6th most competitive on the back of various key factors that place Taiwan in ninth spot globally in terms of digital penetration index and in second spot in terms of the fast-growing telecommunications volume.
In addition, Wu said, Taiwan enjoys the world's No. 1 cellular phone ownership rate of 113 percent and the world's fourth highest broadband penetration rate of 9.4 percent.

All these facts are proof that Taiwan is a major market for worldwide telecommunications businesses and that the country possesses an indispensable importance in WLAN product manufacturing, as the 91 percent of the world's WLAN goods are made in Taiwan, he added.
He also cited all-out government backing as another significant driving force behind the promising domestic industry.

The "M-Taiwan" project and the plan of "10 mobile cities plus 15 special mobile districts" around Taiwan by 2008 being put into practice by the Science and Technology Advisory Group to the Executive Yuan will create a mobile "ubiquitous network" throughout the country to provide people with easy access to the Internet through WLAN and their mobile phones anywhere in Taiwan, he said.

The aim of the "Mobile Taiwan" project is to set up the basic infrastructure to combine cellular phone network service, IT computer platforms, and broadband Internet links, Kao Tien-tzu, head of telecommunication and information section at the advisory group, was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD HOPES TAIWAN CAN MASS PRODUCE FLU VACCINE IN 2 TO 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official expressed hope Tuesday that Taiwan can start to mass produce influenza vaccines within two or three years.

Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen said it is immaterial whether the vaccines will be produced by domestic manufacturers or by joint ventures with foreign manufacturers, as long as the vaccines are produced quickly.
Chen's remarks came at a time when the World Health Organization estimates that there will a major outbreak of influenza in the world within five years.

Chen expressed hope that a special law can be enacted to ensure the survival of domestic vaccine production manufacturers on one hand, but that will also put a restriction on exports, meaning that the vaccines will have to first satisfy the needs of Taiwan before they can be exported to other countries.
"It is a major challenge for Taiwan to guard against the outbreak of influenza," Chen said.

He said that medical literature shows that mainland China's Fujian and Guangdong provinces, two of the provinces located nearest Taiwan opposite Taiwan Strait, are often the sources of new strains of influenza.

Noting that more than 15,000 Taiwan people shuttle across the Taiwan Strait every day, he said that in case of an outbreak on the mainland, Taiwan would bear the brunt of the dire consequences and "for the sake of our own and the world's health, Taiwan will have to contain the disease."
Chen also said that under a "fighting the flu outbreak" project, the DOH will propose a budget of NT$10 billion (US$294.11 million) over the next five years.
The project will include the storage of vaccine -- which only remains viable for five years -- for 10 percent of the nation's 23 million people.

The amount is calculated based on the consideration that not everyone on the island will contract influenza in the event of an outbreak, while economics, age group structure and population concentrations will also be taken into account.

The Department of Health (DOH) will also strengthen the screening of passengers with fever at ports and airports, and will test each individual case within the shortest period of time to learn which strain of virus they are infected with.
The DOH will also step up communications with legislators on the prevention of communicable diseases in the hope that the legislature will pass the relevant legislation in the next session.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE CHIEF MAKES CASE FOR MILITARY BUILD-UP

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye made a case for military build-up Tuesday, claiming that the country will rue the day if it fails to do so.

At a lunch party hosted for local journalists on the eve of Journalist's Day, Lee made an appeal for public support for his ministry's request for a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms purchase from the United States.

He said mainland China is taking a two-pronged approach toward Taiwan -- suffocating the country diplomatically while strengthening its military in an attempt to gain air, sea and missile superiority over Taiwan.

Although there is no military conflict across the Taiwan Strait for the time being, Lee said, Beijing has undertaken non-military warfare against Taiwan in the fields of propaganda and public opinion in order to break down the Taiwan people's willingness to stand against Beijing.
Beijing is also aggressively seeking an excuse to justify an attack on Taiwan, to preempt international interference, Lee claimed.

He claimed that his ministry's plan to acquire PAC-3 Patriot missiles, diesel-electric submarines and anti-submarine aircraft, is meant to close holes in the country's security net. The plan, he said, was formulated to meet the country's military needs and does not involve politics.
The price for the arms purchase could be cut by NT$100 billion if domestic shipbuilders give up their attempts to take part in the building of the eight submarines, Lee went on.

Furthermore, the cost -- to be financed with a special budget over 15 years -- will work out at about NT$33 billion per year, which, combined with the defense ministry's regular budget of NT$264 billion in 2004, will account for 2.85 percent of the country's gross domestic product for that year, he said.
That is relatively low compared to 8 percent for Israel, 4.73 percent for Singapore and 4 percent for the United States, and will not divert the country's regular budget, Lee claimed.

The security of the nation is priceless and the Patriot missiles will boost the people's confidence in the country's security, while submarines and anti-submarine aircraft will be valuable deterrents, according to Lee.

The ministry's request is pending approval by the Legislative Yuan. Critics of the arms purchase plan claim it will drain the country's wealth and increase the arms race between Taiwan and the mainland, which Taiwan cannot afford.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE FIGHTER SORTIES AFFECT TAIWAN'S EARLY-WARNING TIME

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese fighters make nearly 100 sorties on average per month, which adversely affects the early-warning time for Taiwan, according to a 2004 report on the mainland's military might released Tuesday by the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

The MND made the report in its annual report to the Legislative Yuan in the hope of convincing the legislators that a proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms purchase from the United States now pending in the legislature is necessary to help deter the mainland threat.

The report said that the mainland has greatly improved its economy in recent years and that it has spent a lot in the research, development and purchase of state-of-the-art weaponry recently, including the Sukhoi-series of fighters and Kilo-class submarines.
The report said the mainland has in recent years continued to conduct combined forces exercises and that its naval and fishing vessels have continued to expand their areas of operation.

The nearly 100 air sorties per month are part of the mainland's attempts to shorten Taiwan's warning time and as there is no military mutual trust mechanism between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the report said, a confrontation could easily be triggered due to miscalculation.
But the MND also pointed out that the mainland is currently focusing on its economic development and raising the country's profile, for which it needs a stable environment.

The report says that Beijing will continue its verbal attacks and military intimidation and upgrade its military, but the MND estimates that it will refrain from using force against Taiwan for the time being, as long as there is no provocation and as long as Taiwan maintains a military balance with the other side of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT COULD BE QUESTIONED OVER SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Members of a Control Yuan investigative panel said Tuesday they might request the testimony of President Chen Shui-bian to assist their investigation into the administrative responsibilities over the March 19 shooting of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

The panel set up by the watchdog body is made up of Chao Ron-yaw, Chern Jinn-lih and Huang Wu-tzu and is in charge of probing the negligence of security officials concerned, as well as the activation of the "national security mechanism" in the wake of the shooting.

After questioning former and incumbent National Security Council secretaries-general Kang Ning-hsiang and Chiou I-jen, the panel is planning to request Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who chaired the national security contingency meeting, to testify on the process of activating the mechanism, the members said.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party has claimed that the activation of the national security mechanism was one of the reasons leading to their narrow defeat in the presidential election.

According to the alliance, many military servicemen and police officers, most of whom the alliance claims are pan-blue supporters, were unable to vote in the March 20 presidential election because of the mechanism's activation.
It also claims the shooting was set up by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to give it an advantage in the election.
The Control Yuan July 6 impeached eight sitting and former security officials for their slow and sloppy response to the election-eve shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN REMOVES BAN ON POULTRY IMPORTS FROM TAIWAN: BOFT

TEXT.P: Japan has removed its ban on poultry imports from Taiwan, so that poultry produced or raised after June 11 is permitted to enter the Japanese market, a spokesman for the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Tuesday.

According to the BOFT official, the Japanese government made the decision a day earlier after inspection officials sent to Taiwan in early July found that local poultry farms have made full preparations and have imposed controls against any new breakout of bird flu.

Japan imposed the ban Jan. 16, shortly after officials of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA) discovered the H5N2 bird flu virus for the first time on a poultry farm in central Changhua County earlier the same month.
The Cabinet-level COA applied to have the Japanese ban lifted June 11 after a 90-day period had passed without any fresh bird flu cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PLANS TO RECRUIT OVERSEAS MAINLAND CHINESE TALENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan plans to recruit mainland Chinese high-tech experts living abroad in view of a domestic shortage of high-tech manpower, a Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said Tuesday.

CEPD Vice Chairman Thomas M.F. Yeh noted that according to statistics, there will be a need for 1,585 experts with doctorates and 23,193 experts with masters degrees in the next three years, while the current educational system can only supply 1,140 doctorates and 18,579 masters holders in the period.

To overcome the shortfall, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has suggested the introduction of foreign talent, including Indian software experts and overseas mainland Chinese high-tech workers, in addition to the enhancement of high level education and technical training education.
As there are still limitations on the introduction of mainland experts to Taiwan, Chinese professionals living abroad will be the first target in the recruitment plan, a CEPD official said.

Yeh stressed that the high-tech talent recruitment program will not affect the future of domestic experts, as the plan will be a short-term measure and the government will continue strengthening the education and training of domestic experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Procession of speakers invoke Bush's leadership after 9/11.
The Republican Party opened its convention Monday with a searing evocation of the Sept. 11 attacks that leveled the World Trade Center three years ago, as former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York asserted that Senator John Kerry did not have the fortitude to lead the nation through a war on terror. A procession of speakers invoked President Bush's leadership after Sept. 11, 2001.
Wall Street Journal: How stem cells became hurdle for GOP campaign.
Three years ago, President Bush used his first televised presidential address to put the emotional issue of embryonic stem-cell research behind him. As Republicans gather in the New York convention, the stem-cell controversy has grown more divisive. A number of conservative Republican Party stalwarts, including Sens. Trent Lott and Orrin Hatch, have joined Nancy Reagan and party moderates in breaking with the president on the issue. The stem-cell debate shows the power of promising new technology to scramble American politics. The White House has discovered that the yearning for a cure to debilitating diseases doesn't divide along party lines, nor does the new and agonizing moral debate about what constitutes life.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD LOAN RATIO DOWN FURTHER IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan banks made further progress in improving their performance in July, with the average bad loan ratio lowered to 3.53 percent as of the end of the month, a 0.01 percent drop from the June level, a Financial Supervision Commission spokesman reported Tuesday.

The July average also marks a 0.8 percent decrease against the figure posted at the end of December last year, the spokesman said, adding that Taiwan banks had incurred bad loans worth NT$536.5 billion (US$15.8 billion) as of the end of last month.

During the period from January 1999 to July 2004, the banks wrote off bad loans totaling NT$1.289 trillion, 11.79 percent of which was generated by benefits as a result of cuts in corporate taxes and increased reserve funds, according to the spokesman. The remaining 88.21 percent of the bad loans were diminished by the banks with their own business earnings.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VOWS TO PURSUE CROSS-STRAIT PEACE
DOC.DATELINE: Hawaii, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he will lead the people of Taiwan to "pursue peace across the Taiwan Strait and around the world."
Since the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait speak a common language and have common ethnic origins, Chen said, they have no reason to continue their hostility toward each other.

"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should learn from the experience of the United States and Japan, who were enemies during World War II but who have become best friends and working partners, " Chen said.

Chen, who arrived in Hawaii at 3 p.m. Monday for a seven-hour transit stop en route to Panama to attend the Sept. 1 inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Martin Torrijos, made the remarks at a dinner hosted by Taiwanese associations in Hawaii in his honor.

"While touring the USS Arizona Memorial Museum at Pearl Harbor earlier in the day, I had deep feelings for those who sacrificed their lives in war. I firmly believe that peace is the most precious value. Let's say `no' to war. My ultimate life goal is to lead the 23 million Taiwan people to pursue cross-strait peace and to safeguard world peace," Chen said.

After Beijing canceled a planned late-August military exercise on Dongshan Island, Chen said he announced aboard the flight from Taipei to Hawaii the cancellation of Taiwan's Hankuang 20 live-fire training drill originally scheduled for Sept. 9 as show of goodwill toward Beijing.
"Regardless of Beijing's intentions, I'm determined to cancel the Hankuang live-fire drill after consultations with Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, who was in favor of my decision, " Chen said.

When the China Airlines plane carrying Chen and his entourage arrived at Hawaii International Airport, acting Hawaii Governor Mark Bennett, acting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman William Brown and Republic of China Representative to the United States David Lee boarded the plane to greet him.

Hundreds of Taiwan expatriates also turned out to greet Chen when he and his entourage arrived at his hotel. They waved U.S. and ROC flags and chanted "A-bian (Chen's nickname)! Aloha" to welcome the president.
Senator Daniel K. Inouye paid a courtesy call on Chen at his hotel and the president also spoke with Brown and Bennett.
Later, Chen visited the USS Arizona Memorial Museum, which commemorates the military personnel killed in the attack on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese in 1941.
He also toured the battleship USS Missouri, where Japan signed the Instrument of Surrender Sept. 2, 1945 that marked the end of World War II.
Saying that Hawaii can bear witness to the ROC's existence as a sovereign state, Chen noted Hsu Yung-chang represented the ROC at the Instrument of Surrender signing ceremony in 1945.
Chen said he hopes the world can respect and recognize the ROC's continued existence as a sovereign state since 1911. He added that he is the ROC's 11th-term president.

After the dinner, Chen and his entourage left for Panama, after which he is scheduled to travel to Belize Sept. 2 for an official visit. He will make an eight-hour stopover in Seattle on his way back to Taiwan Sept. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY TO HELP FOREIGN BRIDES WITH LIFE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will cooperate with other countries in setting up a consulting mechanism to help foreign and mainland Chinese brides integrate into local society, a MOI official said Tuesday.

The official made the remark in a meeting on ways to take care of the foreign brides, with the participation of officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Education, the Council for Cultural Affairs, local city and county governments, as well as representatives of several civic organizations.
Currently, the number of foreign and mainland Chinese brides living in Taiwan is nearly 300,000.
The MOI move comes in the wake of a case occurring earlier this year in which a Vietnamese bride was maltreated by her Taiwanese husband, resulting in outrage among Vietnamese people.

The MOI decided at the meeting to cooperate with foreign representative offices in Taiwan to offer information about Taiwan's traditions and immigration laws, as well as information related to the rights and obligations of foreign brides, before they come to the island, in a bid to shorten the time takes them to adjust to Taiwan society.

Concerning the children born to these foreign brides, the Ministry of Education will hold meetings regularly with teachers to study and present the best educational services to these so-called "new Taiwanese."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PLANS TO REPATRIATE MORE ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS SEPT. 10

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is scheduled to repatriate another batch of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants Sept. 10, a senior official said Tuesday.
MAC Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks during an informal meeting with local reporters on the eve of Taiwan's Journalist's Day.
After a five-month hiatus, Taiwan managed to repatriate 178 illegal mainland immigrants Tuesday from the frontline island of Matsu, which lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.
Wu said there are still 2,634 illegal mainland immigrants being held at various detention centers.

"We hope mainland China can cooperate with us so that all illegal immigrants can be repatriated as soon as possible, " Wu said, adding that another group of illegals are scheduled to be repatriated Sept. 10.

With the approach of the Mid-Autumn Festival, a traditional family reunion day for Chinese people that falls Sept. 28 this year, Wu said he hopes the mainland authorities will step up preparations for accepting the repatriation of all the illegals.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCELLATION OF MILITARY DRILL DISPLAYS TAIWAN'S GOODWILL: CABINET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's cancellation of an annual live-fire military exercise is a display of Taiwan's goodwill and desire to build peace with mainland China, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Tuesday.

Chen said that the cancellation of the joint forces live-fire exercise, the final part of the Hankuang No. 20 maneuvers that was originally slated for Sept. 9 in southern Taiwan, is in line with the basic tone set by the president in his May 20 inaugural speech.

Claiming that Taiwan will fully engage in making peace across the Taiwan Strait, Chen called for early negotiations with the mainland to better maintain and secure peace between the two sides by reducing tension and miscalculations.

However, the Cabinet spokesman still issued a reminder urging the Taiwan people not to underestimate the mainland's non-military offensive through psychological, legal and public opinion fronts to achieve its unification purpose.

Although it seems that the mainland has pulled out troops from Dongshan Island, where it had planned to carry out a military maneuver in early September, Chen pointed out that according to reliable information, other military exercises in other regions over the past two months have not been scaled down.

President Chen announced Monday the cancellation of the military drill in the wake of a media report that the People's Liberation Army had withdrawn about 3,000 troops from Dongshan Island, where it was to have conducted a simulated attack on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF CONFIDENT OF COPING WITH NEW MAINLAND PROPAGANDA DRIVE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday he is confident that Taiwan can cope with mainland China's new "united front" tactics that reportedly will focus on winning the hearts and minds of southern Taiwan residents.

Quoting a Ministry of National Defense (MND) report, Wu said mainland China will launch a new "united front" propaganda campaign in an attempt to defuse southern Taiwan people's hostility toward the mainland.

According to the MND report, mainland China will step up efforts to court southern Taiwan residents through increased contacts and engagements with grassroots farmers' associations and religious groups.

Wu said that mainland might have become aware that southern Taiwan people are more hostile than elsewhere in the country through the results of Taiwan's recent political elections, including the bitterly fought presidential elections of 2000 and 2004.
As a result, he said, Beijing has decided to step up a "united front" propaganda campaign to woo southern Taiwan residents.
Given Taiwan's open, liberal and pluralistic society, Wu said, the mainland might be able to find easy access to local society.

"Our competitive edge lies in our liberal lifestyle, pluralism and openness. Mainland Chinese visitors will be able to gain a taste of freedom, vitality and vibrancy during their stays here. In the long run, we hope to help sow the seeds of democracy on the mainland through increased civilian exchanges," Wu explained.

Except for a small group of aboriginal tribes, most of Taiwan's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese. But the population can be divided into two ethnic sub-groups -- the "mainlanders" whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese communists took over the mainland in 1949, and the "native Taiwanese" whose ancestors began arriving on the island in the 17th century or earlier.

The mainlanders, about 15 percent of the population, have largely supported the opposition Kuomintang and its ally, the People First Party, and their support base is in northern Taiwan. The native Taiwanese control the south, and they tend to favor President Chen Shui-bian's Democratic Progressive Party and the smaller Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The mainlanders have traditionally supported eventual unification with the mainland, while the native Taiwanese are said by some to lean more toward formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ESTABLISH STABLE CROSS-STRAIT INTERACTION FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: The government is seeking to gradually establish a stable and peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait interaction framework through talks with Beijing based on the principle of equality, according to a written administrative report by the Executive Yuan.

The report, attached to a budget proposal for the central government for 2005, was sent to the Legislative Yuan for its reference. The legislature will open its new session in mid-September and screening the government's budget for next year will be one of its top priorities.

In order to achieve the goal, the report said, the government will continue to promote the normalization of cross-strait trade and economic relations, try to start negotiations on the opening of direct cross-strait trade, transportation and postal services -- the so-called three links, gradually open up investment in Taiwan to the mainland and take concrete measures to allow more mainland people to visit Taiwan for commercial and tourism purposes.

In addition, the government will integrate the public and private sectors to balance and upgrade the quality of cross-strait cultural and educational exchanges under the principles of equality, dignity, active opening, effective management, Taiwan first, peace and reciprocity.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT LAWMAKER SENTENCED TO 13 YEARS IN PRISON

TEXT.P: Independent lawmaker Yen Ching-piao of Taichung County was sentenced Tuesday to 13 years in prison for corruption and attempted murder while serving as a councilor in Taichung County between 1996 and 2000.

The sentence handed down by the Taichung Branch Office of the Taiwan High Court found Yen guilty of spending NT$35 million (US$1.02 million) in public funds from the Taichung County council on dining from 1998 to December 2000, when he served as council speaker.

The deputy speaker of the Taichung county council at the time, Chang Ching-tang, as well as then-secretary-general of the council, Tsai Wen-hsiung, were sentenced to eight years and nine years, respectively, as accomplices in the case.
The three defendants were also ordered by court to repay the NT$35 million.

Yen was also found guilty of attempted murder for a shooting that took place in January, 1996. The court found that Yen ordered his four bodyguards to open fire with an assault rifle and handguns on a car driven by a person who Yen suspected of having tried to blackmail him.
In two previous trials, Yen was found guilty on both charges and was given jail terms of 20 years and 11-and-a-half years, respectively.
Although Yen was taken into custody, he ran in absentia for a lawmaker seat in 2001 and won a seat in the Legislative Yuan.

He was released on bail in 2002 after being found guilty of corruption and attempted murder in the second trial and became the leader of the 13-member Alliance of Independent Legislators at the Legislative Yuan recently.
Yen could not be reached for comment Tuesday, but one of his aides said the sentence will not discourage Yen from serving his homeland and that he will appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CHAIRS MEETING OF DPP CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE FOR FIRST TIME

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu chaired a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Central Standing Committee in the place of President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday for the first time. Chen is also the DPP chairman.

Emerging from her debut as acting chairwoman of the DPP Standing Committee, Lu told waiting journalists that it was an exciting and pleasant experience and that the discussion at the meeting was brisk.

Legislator Trong Chai, who is a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee, said the meeting was successful and that the atmosphere was much easier than when Chen presides, probably, he said, because Lu is female.

Lawmaker and Central Standing Committee member Ker Chien-ming said the meeting attendees, who tend to be more cautiously when speaking at meetings chaired by Chen, spoke more freely at Tuesday's meeting.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Chung Chia-ping told journalists after the meeting that Lu issued two instructions after the discussion, the first of which reconfirmed the party's opposition to a statute railroaded through by the opposition for the formation of a committee to investigate the March 19 shooting of Chen and herself.
Decrying the statute as unconstitutional, Lu said the DPP cannot yield to the abuse of legislative power by the opposition, which controls the Legislative Yuan.

In her second instruction, Lu called on the police to solve the March 19 shooting as soon as possible in order to preempt the opposition's attempts to interfere with the investigation by a committee formed on their terms.
As a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee, Lu was asked by Chen to take his place at the meeting during his visit to Panama.
